answer_html: \(f'(x)=- \sqrt{\cos{x}} + e^{x} \sqrt{\cos{e^{x}}}\) where in the last equality on the right most sum, we used the chain rule to compute the derivative.This completes the question.
answer_latex:
$f'(x)=- \sqrt{\cos{x}} +  e^{x} \sqrt{\cos{e^{x}}}$ where in the last equality on the right most sum, we used the chain rule
to compute the derivative.This completes the question.
hints_html:
Use the fundamental theorem of calculus.

Remember that the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus says

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx}\int_a^x g(t) dt = g(x)\end{aligned}\]

(where a is any fixed real number).

The integral given in this problem has a function of x in both bounds (top and bottom). You can split the integral into two parts to obtain the form in the previous hint.

(top and bottom). You can split the integral into two parts to obtain
the form in the previous hint.

Remember that the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus says 

:<math> \frac{d}{dx}\int_a^x g(t) dt = g(x) </math>

(where ''a'' is any fixed real number).
The integral given in this problem has a function of x in both bounds (top and bottom). You can split the integral into two parts to obtain the form in the previous hint.
question: 1 (i)
sols_html:
Using the fundamental theorem of calculus, we have

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx}\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt \\ &= \frac{d}{dx}\left( \int_x^{0} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt + \int_{0}^{e^{x}} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt\right)\\ &= \frac{d}{dx}\left( -\int_{0}^{x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt + \int_{0}^{e^{x}} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt\right)\\ &= - \sqrt{\cos{x}} + e^{x} \sqrt{\cos{e^{x}}}\end{aligned}\]

where in the last equality on the right most sum, we used the chain rule to compute the derivative. This completes the question.
statement_html:
Calculate the derivative \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) if

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)=\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Calculate the derivative <math>\displaystyle f'(x) </math> if
:<math>
f(x)=\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt.
</math>
